summary_points: 1. Universal Health Services, Inc.'s (UHS) reported net income attributable to UHS in Q1 2025 was $316.7 million ($4.80 per diluted share), a 20.9% increase compared to Q1 2024.

2.  Despite a $36 million decrease in net cash provided by operating activities year-over-year,  this was primarily due to delays in Medicaid supplemental payments, some of which were retroactively approved in April 2025.

3. UHS faces future risks from changes in government healthcare programs, potentially impacting 2025 operating results, and significant increases in borrowing rates, which could materially impact future operating results and access to capital.
1. On April 28, 2025, Genuine Parts Company's Board of Directors declared a regular quarterly cash dividend of $1.03 per share, payable July 2, 2025, to shareholders of record on June 6, 2025.

2. At the 2025 Annual Meeting of Shareholders (April 28, 2025), a shareholder proposal requesting a report on the Company's diversity, equity, and inclusion efforts was rejected by a vote of 19,248,383 for and 84,672,725 against.

3. Four directors (Elizabeth W. Camp, Gary P. Fayard, John D. Johns, and Wendy B. Needham) retired from the board on April 29, 2025, due to reaching the mandatory retirement age, while Laurie Schupmann was elected as a new director.

1. Entergy Corporation reported first-quarter 2025 earnings per share of 82 cents on both an as-reported and adjusted basis, significantly higher than the 18 cents (as-reported) and 54 cents (adjusted) from the first quarter of 2024.
2.  The Utility business reported a substantial year-over-year increase in earnings, from $350 million (adjusted) in Q1 2024 to $490 million (adjusted) in Q1 2025.
3. Entergy affirmed its 2025 adjusted earnings per share guidance range of $3.75 to $3.95 (as of April 29, 2025).
1. Alan Spoon, a director, will not be standing for re-election at the 2025 Annual Meeting; his departure is not due to any disagreements with the company.
2. Kelly Campbell will be nominated as a new director, effective at the 2025 Annual Meeting, increasing the Board size to eleven directors.
3. Anson Funds agreed to withdraw its director nominations and proposal to declassify the board following an information-sharing agreement with Match Group.
1. Sysco's Q3 2025 sales increased by 1.1% to $19.6 billion despite decreased U.S. Foodservice volume due to external factors.
2.  Sysco's Q3 2025 net income decreased by 11.0% to $478 million, and diluted earnings per share decreased by 11.6% to $0.81.
3. Sysco projects approximately 3% sales growth and at least 1% adjusted EPS growth for FY25 (ending June 2025).
1. Ecolab's Q1 2025 organic sales grew 3% year-over-year, but reported sales decreased 2% due to a business sale and currency impacts.
2. Despite a soft market, Ecolab maintained its full-year 2025 adjusted diluted EPS outlook of $7.42 to $7.62 (a 12% to 15% increase from 2024).
3. While adjusted diluted EPS increased 12% to $1.50, reported diluted EPS slightly decreased by 1% to $1.41 in Q1 2025.
1. PACCAR's Q1 2025 net income was $505.1 million, down significantly from expectations due to a $264.5 million after-tax charge related to European civil litigation.
2.  Despite a decrease in overall revenue, PACCAR Parts revenue reached a record $1.69 billion in Q1 2025.
3. PACCAR plans to invest $600–$900 million in its Amplify Cell Technologies battery joint venture, with production anticipated to begin in 2027.

1. Pfizer announced an additional $1.2 billion in anticipated cost savings by the end of 2027, resulting from their cost realignment program, but expects one-time costs of approximately $1.6 billion to achieve these savings.
2. First-quarter 2025 revenues were $13.7 billion, an 8% decrease year-over-year, primarily due to a significant decline in Paxlovid revenues (down 75% operationally).
3. Pfizer reaffirmed its full-year 2025 financial guidance,  projecting revenues in a range of $61.0 to $64.0 billion and adjusted diluted EPS in a range of $2.80 to $3.00 (as of April 29, 2025).
1. Norfolk Southern Corp issued $400,000,000 in 5.100% Senior Notes due 2035 on April 28, 2025, with net proceeds estimated at $395.75 million.
2.  The offering is expected to close around May 2, 2025,  subject to customary closing conditions.
3. The net proceeds from the note sale will be used for general corporate purposes.

1. Corpay, Inc. announced a new partnership with Mastercard, Inc. in cross-border payments on April 29, 2025, resulting in Mastercard becoming a minority investor in Corpay's cross-border business unit.
2. Mastercard's $300 million investment represents an approximate 3% equity stake in Corpay, resulting in an enterprise valuation of $10.7 billion.
3. Corpay expects Mastercard's sponsorship to accelerate its financial institution revenue growth.
1. Zebra Technologies Corp reported first-quarter 2025 net sales of $1,308 million, an 11.3% year-over-year increase.
2. Non-GAAP diluted earnings per share (EPS) increased 41.5% year-over-year to $4.02 in the first quarter of 2025.
3.  The company anticipates a $70 million U.S. import tariff expense for the full year 2025, impacting its adjusted EBITDA margin, which is now expected to be between 20% and 21%.
1. Teradyne's Q1 2025 revenue was $686 million, a 14% year-over-year increase driven by strong Semiconductor Test performance, specifically System-on-a-Chip (SoC) for mobile.
2.  As of April 29th, 2025, Teradyne increased its share repurchase program from a target of $400 million in 2025 to up to $1 billion, to be completed by the end of 2026.

3. Second quarter 2025 revenue is projected to be between $610 million and $680 million, but visibility for the second half of the year is limited due to market uncertainty and the impact of trade policy.

1. General Motors (GM) reported first-quarter 2025 revenue of $44.0 billion, net income attributable to stockholders of $2.8 billion, and EBIT-adjusted of $3.5 billion, representing year-over-year decreases of 6.6%, and 9.8% respectively.
2. GM's automotive operating cash flow decreased by 33.2% year-over-year to $2.4 billion in Q1 2025.

3.  GM rescheduled its conference call for investors and analysts to May 1, 2025, to discuss first-quarter results and updated 2025 full-year guidance due to recent trade policy updates, which were not initially factored into their guidance.
1. Welltower's cash and cash equivalents increased by $1.13 billion year-over-year to $3.6 billion as of March 31, 2025.
2. The Amica Senior Lifestyles acquisition, expected to close late 2025 or early 2026, will involve C$560 million in secured debt at a 3.6% interest rate.
3. Welltower's At The Market (ATM) program's authorized amount decreased between April 30th and April 29th, 2025, with the precise amount unknown.
1. Altria's net earnings decreased 49.4% year-over-year in Q1 2025, reaching $1,077 million, primarily due to lower operating income, unfavorable investment results, and unfavorable income tax items.
2.  A $873 million non-cash goodwill impairment was recorded on March 31, 2025, due to the ITC's ban on NJOY ACE, which Altria is appealing, though a stay during the appeal is unlikely.
3.  Altria anticipates additional pre-tax costs of $100 million to $125 million in Q2 2025 related to its Optimize & Accelerate initiative.

1. Sherwin-Williams' Q1 2025 consolidated net sales decreased by 1.1% year-over-year to $5.31 billion, primarily due to unfavorable currency translation and lower sales in the Performance Coatings and Consumer Brands Groups, partially offset by higher sales in the Paint Stores Group.
2.  Adjusted diluted net income per share for Q1 2025 increased by 3.7% year-over-year to $2.25.

3.  The company reaffirmed its full-year 2025 diluted net income per share guidance in the range of $10.70 to $11.10 per share (as of April 29, 2025), and expects demand softness to persist in several end markets well into the second half of the year.
1. Corning Inc.'s first-quarter 2025 core sales increased by 13% year-over-year to $3.7 billion, while core EPS surged 42% year-over-year to $0.54.
2. The Enterprise sales within Optical Communications segment experienced a significant 106% year-over-year increase due to strong demand for Gen AI products.

3. Corning anticipates continued strong year-over-year growth in the second quarter of 2025, projecting core sales of approximately $3.85 billion and core EPS in the range of $0.55 to $0.59, although this guidance includes estimated impacts from tariffs and temporarily higher production costs.
1. S&P Global Inc. announced its intention to separate its Mobility segment into a standalone public company on April 29, 2025, aiming to maximize shareholder value and simplify operations.
2.  First-quarter 2025 revenue reached a record $3.777 billion, an 8% increase year-over-year.

3. The company lowered its full-year 2025 adjusted free cash flow guidance to $5.6–$5.8 billion from a prior expectation of ~$6.0 billion due to changes in assumptions for cash taxes, net income, and working capital.
1. Incyte Corporation's total revenues for the first fiscal quarter ended March 31, 2025, were $1,053 million, a 20% year-over-year increase.

2. Jakafi® net product revenues increased 24% year-over-year to $709 million in Q1 2025, driven by increased paid demand, the Inflation Reduction Act's Part D redesign, and less de-stocking than in Q1 2024.
3. Incyte plans to initiate Phase 3 studies for its CDK2 inhibitor (INCB123667) in ovarian cancer in 2025 and anticipates Phase 3 data for tafasitamab in the second half of 2025.
1. Xylem Inc. reported first-quarter 2025 revenue of $2.1 billion, a 2% increase on a reported basis and a 3% increase organically, as of April 29, 2025.
2.  Adjusted earnings per share for Q1 2025 were $1.03, a 14% year-over-year increase compared to Q1 2024.
3. Xylem Inc. reaffirmed its full-year 2025 adjusted earnings per share guidance of $4.50 to $4.70, as of April 29, 2025, despite current market volatility.

1. American Tower Corporation's net income decreased by 45.9% to $499 million in Q1 2025, primarily due to foreign currency losses of approximately $(345.7) million compared to foreign currency gains of approximately $127.7 million in Q1 2024, and a gain on the sale of South Africa Fiber.
2.  Despite the significant net income decrease, Adjusted EBITDA increased by 1.9% to $1,744 million in Q1 2025.

3.  American Tower projects total property revenue for the full year 2025 to be between $9,970 million and $10,120 million, a midpoint growth rate of 1.1% compared to the prior year,  with the midpoint growth rate for AFFO attributable to AMT common stockholders, as adjusted, of 5.0%.

1. Altria Group, Inc. reported a 5.7% decrease in net revenues for the first quarter of 2025, primarily due to lower net revenues in the smokeable products segment, compared to the same period in 2024.
2.  Despite a 47.9% decrease in reported diluted EPS to $0.63, adjusted diluted EPS increased by 6.0% to $1.23 for the first quarter of 2025 compared to the same period in 2024.

3. The company reaffirms its full-year 2025 adjusted diluted EPS growth rate guidance of 2% to 5% versus 2024, resulting in an expected range of $5.30 to $5.45, but this is contingent on various factors including the economy, consumer behavior, illicit product enforcement, and regulatory developments.

1. Kraft Heinz's Q1 2025 net sales decreased by 6.4% year-over-year to $6.0 billion, primarily due to a 5.6 percentage point decline in volume/mix, partially offset by a 0.9 percentage point increase in price.
2.  Kraft Heinz lowered its full-year 2025 outlook, now expecting organic net sales to be down 1.5% to 3.5% and constant currency adjusted operating income to be down 5% to 10%, as of April 29, 2025.

3. The company anticipates an approximate $0.23 headwind to its full-year 2025 adjusted EPS due to several countries enacting global minimum tax regulations, partially offset by benefits from a 2024 corporate restructuring.
1. As of April 29, 2025, PayPal Holdings, Inc. reported a 3% year-over-year increase in total payment volume to $417.2 billion, despite a 7% decrease in payment transactions.
2.  PayPal's GAAP operating income increased by 31% year-over-year to $1.5 billion in the quarter ending March 31, 2025, while non-GAAP operating income rose by 16% to $1.6 billion.
3.  Despite a strong first quarter, PayPal maintained its full-year guidance for 2025 due to uncertainty in the global macroeconomic environment.
1. Coca-Cola's net revenues declined 2% year-over-year to $11.1 billion in Q1 2025, despite 6% organic revenue growth.
2.  While Q1 2025 operating income surged 71%, this was significantly inflated by accounting adjustments;  currency-neutral operating income only grew 10%.
3. Coca-Cola projects 5-6% organic revenue growth for 2025, but anticipates significant currency headwinds impacting net revenue (2-3%) and EPS (5-6%).
1. A. O. Smith Corporation reported first-quarter 2025 sales of $964 million, a 2% decrease year-over-year, primarily due to lower water heater volumes in North America and China.
2.  Diluted earnings per share decreased by 5% year-over-year to $0.95 in the first quarter of 2025.
3. The company maintained its full-year 2025 outlook of flat to up 2% consolidated sales and diluted EPS in a range of $3.60 to $3.90, despite uncertainty surrounding tariffs.
1. Labcorp's Q1 2025 revenue increased to $3.35 billion from $3.18 billion in Q1 2024, a 5.3% increase, but diluted EPS decreased to $2.52 from $2.69.
2.  As of March 31, 2025, Labcorp held $0.37 billion in cash and cash equivalents and $5.57 billion in total debt.

3. Labcorp reaffirmed its 2025 revenue and free cash flow guidance (6.7% to 8.0% revenue growth and $1.10 billion to $1.25 billion in free cash flow), but raised the midpoint of its adjusted EPS guidance by $0.05 to a range of $15.70 to $16.40.
1. Regeneron's Q1 2025 net income increased by $86.7 million compared to Q1 2024, despite a 39% decline in EYLEA U.S. net product sales due to biosimilar competition.
2.  Regeneron's contingent reimbursement obligation to Sanofi totaled $1.453 billion as of March 31, 2025, with only 20% of quarterly collaboration profits applied towards repayment.
3.  Biocon's launch of an aflibercept biosimilar has been delayed until the second half of 2026 due to settled litigation with Regeneron.
1. Regeneron Pharmaceuticals, Inc. reported first-quarter 2025 revenues of $3.0 billion, a 4% decrease year-over-year, with GAAP diluted EPS of $7.27 and non-GAAP diluted EPS of $8.22.
2.  EYLEA HD U.S. net sales increased by 54% year-over-year to $307 million in Q1 2025, while total U.S. EYLEA HD and EYLEA net sales decreased by 26% year-over-year to $1.04 billion.

3. The FDA issued a Complete Response Letter (CRL) on April 23, 2025, for Regeneron's EYLEA HD pre-filled syringe submission, delaying its launch;  the FDA also rejected an application for extended dosing intervals for EYLEA HD, citing insufficient data.
1. Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd. reported Q1 2025 EPS of $2.70 and adjusted EPS of $2.71, exceeding company guidance due to stronger-than-expected pricing and lower costs (as of April 29, 2025).

2.  Compared to Q1 2024, Q1 2025 saw a 100% increase in Net Income ($0.7 billion vs. $0.4 billion), a 40% increase in Adjusted Net Income ($0.7 billion vs. $0.5 billion), a 9% increase in guests served (2.2 million vs. 2.05 million), and a 13.9% increase in as-reported Gross Margin Yields.
3. Royal Caribbean Group increased its full-year 2025 adjusted EPS guidance to $14.55-$15.55, representing approximately 28% year-over-year growth (as of April 29, 2025).
1. NXP's Q1 2025 revenue decreased by 9.3% year-over-year to $2.8 billion.
2. NXP plans to complete three acquisitions (Aviva Links, TTTech Auto, and Kinara, Inc.) totaling $1,174.5 million in 2025.
3.  NXP's adoption of new accounting standards (ASU 2023-09 and evaluation of ASU 2024-03) may impact future financial reporting starting in 2027.
1. UPS's consolidated revenues decreased by 0.7% year-over-year in the first quarter of 2025, totaling $21.5 billion compared to $21.7 billion in Q1 2024.
2.  Despite the revenue decline, consolidated operating profit increased by 3.3% year-over-year to $1.7 billion in Q1 2025.
3.  Due to macroeconomic uncertainty, UPS is not providing an updated full-year outlook as of April 29, 2025.
1. Honeywell International Inc. exceeded its first-quarter 2025 guidance on all metrics, reporting 8% year-over-year sales growth and 4% organic sales growth.

2.  Despite macroeconomic uncertainty, Honeywell maintained its full-year organic growth guidance (2-5%) and raised its adjusted earnings per share guidance to $10.20-$10.50 (up 5 cents at the midpoint from prior guidance).
3. Honeywell plans to separate its Automation and Aerospace businesses, and spin off its Advanced Materials business, resulting in three publicly-listed companies by the second half of 2026.
1. Hilton's Q1 2025 diluted EPS increased by 18% year-over-year, reaching $1.23.
2. Hilton's development pipeline expanded by 7% year-over-year to 503,400 rooms as of March 31, 2025.
3. Hilton projects full-year 2025 adjusted EBITDA to be between $3,650 million and $3,710 million.
1. As of April 28, 2025, News Corp had repurchased approximately US$666,231,474.49 worth of Class A and Class B shares under its US$1 billion stock repurchase program.
2. On April 28, 2025, News Corp repurchased 21,663,857 Class A shares and 10,692,689 Class B shares.

3. News Corp's stock repurchase program, announced previously, is ongoing and intends to repurchase up to US$1 billion of Class A and Class B common stock, subject to market conditions and other factors.
1. Noelle K. Eder resigned from the Ameren Corporation Board of Directors on April 22, 2025, effective May 6, 2025, due to relocation outside the United States.
2.  The filing is an 8-K current report, indicating a significant event requiring immediate disclosure to the SEC.
3. The resignation of Noelle K. Eder doesn't appear to present any immediate financial or operational risks to the company.
1. IPG's organic net revenue decreased by 3.6% in Q1 2025,  a result aligning with prior predictions but exacerbated by significant account losses.
2. IPG's Q1 2025 adjusted diluted EPS remained flat year-over-year at $0.33.
3. IPG anticipates $300 to $350 million in restructuring charges in 2025, with equivalent annual cost savings expected for the merged Omnicom entity beginning in 2026.
1. Waste Management Inc. reported first-quarter 2025 revenue of $6,018 million, a 16.7% year-over-year increase, driven primarily by a 6.5% core price increase and 4.0% Collection and Disposal yield.
2. Adjusted operating EBITDA for the WM Legacy Business grew 6.0% year-over-year to $1,593 million, with a margin of 30% for the fourth consecutive quarter.

3. WM Healthcare Solutions contributed $95 million in adjusted operating EBITDA in the first quarter of 2025, and the company expects to achieve $80 to $100 million in synergies in 2025 from the Stericycle acquisition.
1. Constellation Brands, Inc. amended and restated its Tenth Amended and Restated Credit Agreement, refinancing $2.25 billion in commitments and extending the maturity date to April 28, 2030.
2. The general liens basket under the amended credit agreement increased from 7.5% to 10.0% of consolidated tangible assets.

3.  As of April 28, 2025, Constellation Brands and its subsidiaries had existing financial relationships with certain Credit Agreement Lenders and their affiliates, including services for which customary fees are paid and derivative arrangements.
1. Brown & Brown, Inc.'s Q1 2025 net income increased 13% year-over-year to $331 million.
2.  The company has significantly increased its debt, reaching $3,806 million by March 31, 2025, a $225 million increase from the previous quarter.

3. Brown & Brown, Inc. anticipates a total of $865 million in intangible asset amortization expense from 2025 to 2029 and is facing numerous legal proceedings with potentially material impacts on its financials.
1. Brown & Brown, Inc. reported total revenues of $1.4 billion for the first quarter of 2025, an 11.6% increase year-over-year.
2. Diluted net income per share increased to $1.15 in Q1 2025, a 12.7% year-over-year rise, while adjusted diluted net income per share reached $1.29, a 13.2% increase.
3. The company declared a regular quarterly cash dividend of $0.15 per share, payable on May 21, 2025, to shareholders of record on May 12, 2025.
1. Nucor's first-quarter 2025 net earnings decreased 81% year-over-year, from $845 million to $156 million.
2. This decrease was attributed to lower average selling prices and reduced steel mill volumes.
3. Nucor anticipates higher second-quarter 2025 earnings compared to the first quarter, driven by increased prices and volumes in certain segments.
